qas.question: What is another way of phrasing "time order"?
What never precedes cause because of causality?
In what ways can a sequence of events be presented?

answers.text: in text, tables, charts, or timelines

qas.question: What may the description of events include?
A sequence of events used to describe a sequential path can be referred to as what?
What is another way of phrasing "sequence of events"?
What never precedes cause because of timelines?

plausible_answers.text: in text, tables, charts, or timelines

qas.question: In what ways can a sequence of relationships be presented?
What may the description of relationships include?
What can a sequence of relationships used to describe a sequential path be referred to as?

context: A sequence of events, or series of events, is a sequence of items, facts, events, actions, changes, or procedural steps, arranged in time order <b5_0>(<a0_0>chronological order<b5_0/><a0_0/>), often with causality relationships among the items. Because of causality, cause precedes <b6_0>effect<b6_0/>, or cause and effect may appear together in a single item, but <a1_0>effect<a1_0/> never precedes cause. A sequence of events can be presented <a2_0><b7_0>in text, tables, charts, or timelines<b7_0/><a2_0/>. The description of the items or events may include <a3_0><b8_0>a timestamp<b8_0/><a3_0/>. A sequence of events that includes the time along with place or location information to describe a sequential path may be referred to as <a4_0><b9_0>a world line<b9_0/><a4_0/>.
